Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Authentic Project-based Research in College Sciences Curricula: Assessing the Impacts on Students and Faculty

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaboration among Seattle Pacific University, Augustana College, the University of Arizona, and Hiram College will formally evaluate the impact of authentic project-based research in core sciences curricula. In a previous CCLI project, the PI team constructed the Genomics Education National Initiative (GENI portal), a web-based project delivery system that provides remote access to authentic research. GENI supports classroom implementation of this research by providing protocols, training materials, expert advice, a networking community, and physical resources. The PI team is using this resource to integrate authentic project-based research into the curricula of five participating institutions (those listed above and the University of Wisconsin Madison). The PI team is also inviting current and future users of the program to participate in this assessment. The project is focusing on the evaluation of student learning, engagement, scientific literacy, problem-solving, and retention in the sciences and will study factors that influence faculty integration of authentic research into courses. In addition, they are evaluating the utility of the GENI portal curricula delivery system.

The Intellectual Merit of the proposed project lies in the systematic implementation and assessment of authentic project-based research in science curricula. These results will add to the limited research base on the effectiveness of integrating authentic research in major and non-major components of core science curricula across multiple disciplines and institutions. Through the use of mixed research methods, including controlled studies and qualitative approaches, data are being collected regarding the impact of authentic project-based research on student learning, attitudes, science career involvement and retention, problem solving, and collaboration. A focus on process and context variables is providing critical information regarding integration of authentic research into core science curricula including benefits and challenges for faculty and students, the role of an electronic delivery and project management system, and their use in multiple settings and across disciplines.

The Broader Impacts of this proposal reside in the comprehensive application of project-based research as the foundation of institutional change in undergraduate education. The combination of the resources provided by the GENI portal and the community it supports, complemented by in-depth assessment across multiple educational levels will facilitate integration of research at institutions that were unable to offer a high-quality research experience to their students and will allow the integration of research across curricula, making it an outstanding tool for reaching underserved populations and non-majors. It also provides a way for instructional faculty to re-integrate with mainstream research communities and for full-time researchers to disseminate their science to students of all levels at any institution or location. The data produced will help faculty and administrators integrate undergraduate research at their institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
GENI: Guiding Education through Novel Investigation

The GENI program offers undergraduate students and teachers the opportunity to work together on authentic research projects in the classroom.  GENI projects model the scientific process from exploring scientific literature and developing experiments, to collecting, analyzing and publishing data - all of which contribute valuable information to the broader scientific community. Collaboration is foundational in science and GENI allows users to join existing projects, or create their own to share with other users.  GENI’s web-based portal provides students and instructors access to projects that span multiple disciplines from genomics, to biochemistry and molecular genetics. Projects provide shared instructor resources, equipment & materials lists, background information, detailed protocols, and data collection. Projects can be implemented at all levels from high school through community college and undergraduate classrooms. Bioinformatics resources allow instructors to investigate microbial genomes using only a computer, while in-depth protocols and tips from professionals facilitate bench research across disciplines. 

Accomplishments during the granting period include:

 Assessment: The Student Science Learning Gains (SSLG) survey was designed during this project. Information from this survey was used to better understand how being involved in authentic research in the classroom impacts student perceptions about how science works, how to solve problems, collaboration, learning, interest and engagement, scientific literacy and desire to continue in STEM disciplines or work in related fields. Student and faculty interviews were conducted to more deeply investigate each of these areas.

Pre and post course surveys were paired and examined to explore expected outcomes from students' participation in authentic research projects. Moderate to large effect sizes were observed with respect to content learning, scientific inquiry skills, confidence and self-efficacy and transferrence of knowledge.

Instructors reported that students are more challenged and more deeply engaged in authentic research as compared to traditional laboratory courses.

Program Expansion: Our group had an unexpected opportunity to merge with a related program - The Annotation Collaboration Toolkit (ACT) developed at the Joint Genome Institute during this grant period. ACT brings bioinformatics resources and computer-based analyses of bacterial genomes to complement the GENI focus on laboratory bench research. The two groups, both supported by the National Science Foundation, merged to create a single more versatile educational resource called Guiding Education through Novel Investigation - Academic Collaboration Tools, or GENI-ACT (geni-act.org).

Website: The GENI and ACT websites began integration in the last year of this project. This new program serves as the foundation for ongoing NSF supported work to establish a broad community network of educators using these resources to help them integrate authentic research projects into classrooms nationwide. 

Dissemination: The GENI-ACT program was shared with educators across the nation through workshops, talks and posters presented by our faculty at 35 professional conferences nationwide. Students involved in our projects shared their findings at 17 national and regional meetings. An overview of the GENI-ACT program and how it was implemented in a biochemistry curriculum has recently been published as a chapter in the ACS eBook entitled Teaching and the Internet: The Application of Web Apps, Networking, and Online Tech for Chemistry Education.

If you’re curious to know more about this program and/or would like to implement GENI-ACT in your classroom, please visit us at GENI-ACT.org.
